definition[0]: the number of people killed or injured in a particular accident, by a particular illness etc
example[0]: The death toll has risen to 83.
example[1]: The bombings took a heavy toll, killing hundreds of Londoners.
definition[1]: a very bad effect that something has on something or someone over a long period of time
example[2]: Years of smoking have taken their toll on his health.
example[3]: a heavy toll on the environment
definition[2]: the money you have to pay to use a particular road, bridge etc
definition[3]: the sound of a large bell ringing slowly
definition[4]: if a large bell tolls, or if you toll it, it keeps ringing slowly, especially to show that someone has died
example[4]: In parts of the USA tolls are charged for motorways.
example[5]: Revenue is raised through customs duties and road tolls.
definition[5]: to have a very bad effect on something or someone over a long period of time
example[6]: Rising unemployment has taken its toll on the consumer lending market.
